text: The concept of autonomy in second/foreign language learning and teaching has been
label: body

text: the focus of attention for many researchers and practitioners for more than three
label: body

text: decades. According to Benson (2001), the notion of autonomy was introduced and
label: body

text: popularized in 1981 by Henri Holec in his seminal report for the Council of Europe
label: body

text: autonomy in the context of language learning as “the ability to take charge of one’s own
label: body

text: learning” (Holec, 1981, p. 3). Holec’s idea of autonomy encompasses some components
label: body

text: and capacities on the part of language learners (e.g. self-directed learning). For some
label: body

text: other authors autonomy also involves “a capacity – for detachment, critical reflection,
label: body

text: decision-making, and independent action” (Little, 1991, p. 4) and “the capacity to take
label: body

text: control of one’s own learning” (Benson, 2001, p. 46). As stated by Benson (2011, p.
label: body

text: 16), “autonomy is multidimensional and takes many different forms according to the
label: body

text: person, the setting, and multiple contextual and micro-contextual factors” and it is “a
label: body

text: multi-faceted concept that consists of several layers” (Reinders, 2011, p. 48) whose
label: body

text: roots are based in political, societal and educational developments. In addition to this,
label: body

text: work on autonomy emphasizes social dimensions of learner autonomy in view of the
label: body

text: fact that “autonomous learners always do things for themselves, but they may or may
label: body

text: not do things on their own” (Little, 2009, p. 223) and that by means of social
label: body

text: interactions language learners “develop a capacity to analyze, reflect upon and
label: body

text: synthesize information to create new perspectives” (Lee, 2011, p. 88). It should also be
label: body

label: body

label: body

text: classroom-based approaches (Benson, 2011). Finally, it has to be added that
label: body

label: body

text: by Benson (2011): “(a) language learners naturally tend to take control of their
label: body

label: body

label: body

text: Perhaps in order to define the concept of autonomy in language learning it is necessary

label: body

label: body

text: capacity depends on two major components such as ability and willingness, and he
label: body

text: claims that the attributes can also be further subdivided. Thus, ability depends on
label: body

label: body

text: choose the most suitable alternatives. When it comes to willingness, this depends on
label: body

text: having motivation and confidence in order to take responsibility for adequate choices.
label: body

text: Moreover, Littlewood (1996) argues that if an individual is to be successful in being
label: body

label: body

label: body

label: body

label: body

label: body

text: The picture that emerges from the analysis of the collected data regarding the advanced
label: body

text: learners' use of mobile devices for learning English is relatively encouraging. This is
label: body

text: because all the study participants used, at least to some extent, their mobile devices
label: body

text: (i.e. smartphones and/or tablet computers) in order to learn the English language
label: body

text: autonomously. Moreover, the positive impact of using mobile devices for English study
label: body

text: was acknowledged by the majority of the interviewees. Their beneficial contribution to
label: body

text: their English development was chiefly linked with easy access to English language
label: body

text: resources, the opportunity to store them, comfort in using their smartphones and
label: body

text: tablets anywhere and anytime as well as perceived gains in English learning. The results
label: body

text: of the study also showed that all interviewees engaged with their smartphones and/or
label: body

text: tablet computers to practice the target language vocabulary (plus some students also
label: body

text: claimed to learn pronunciation of English words) and the majority of the subjects used
label: body

text: their mobile devices autonomously in their leisure time as well as during language
label: body

text: classes. Such a state of affairs can be explained in terms of increased awareness on the
label: body

text: part of some students of the beneficial role of MobDs in foreign language learning, their
label: body

text: ability to reach for appropriate tools and retrieve needed information to achieve their
label: body

text: goals and adjust their learning of the target language to their personal learning styles.
label: body

text: Despite this positive view of MobDs reported by the study participants, the results of the
label: body

text: study also revealed that only a few subjects engaged with their mobile devices to
label: body

text: master target language skills such as reading, listening, writing and speaking as well as
label: body

text: English language grammar. In addition, some interviewees limited themselves to a
label: body

text: rather intuitive and perhaps even spontaneous use of their mobile devices in the
label: body

text: language classroom. It should also be noted that almost half of the subjects regarded
label: body

text: themselves as quite inexperienced in using their mobile devices when it comes to
label: body

text: learning the English language despite the fact that some of the students had been using
label: body

text: them with the intention of learning English for years. Taking all these findings into
label: body

text: account, one may conclude that this is due to a failure or underestimation of the role
label: body

text: and place of mobile devices in foreign language learning and teaching on the part of
label: body

text: language teachers. It seems therefore warranted to say that the subjects’ use of mobile
label: body

text: devices could be altered if teachers took into account the benefits they may offer. For
label: body

text: this reason language teachers should, for instance, present the affordances of mobile
label: body

text: technology and discuss them with students during language classes. They should also
label: body

text: select mobile apps and create opportunities for using them in- and out-of-class learning
label: body

text: by offering or designing tasks devoted to practicing a variety of language skills and
label: body

text: subsystems suitable for the use of such devices. If this were to happen, teachers need
label: body

text: to respond quickly to the constant and dynamic changes in contemporary
label: body

text: foreign/second language learning and teaching contexts by undergoing official teacher
label: body

text: training not only in the area of technology-mediated language learning and teaching but
label: body

text: also in the context of learner autonomy.
label: body

text: As with all studies, the study reported in this paper has some limitations. Although the
label: body

text: interviewees represented a range of experience of English language learning, the small
label: body

text: number of participants reduces the generalizability of the results. Another limitation is
label: body

text: related to the fact that the group was largely homogenous, i.e. the subjects came from
label: body

text: the same institution and all studied English. Yet another weakness may concern the
label: body

text: data collection instrument, namely the semi-structured interview which was conducted
label: body

text: only once. Perhaps a different set of questions, their wording or a series of such
label: body

text: interviews carried out over a particular period of time (say one academic year) may
label: body

text: have yielded more detailed and insightful results. Despite these limitations, this study
label: body

text: provided some insights into why and how advanced English language learners engage
label: body

text: with their mobile devices to develop learning experiences. It should be stressed,
label: body

text: however, that teacher involvement in creating conditions conducive to the use of mobile
label: body

text: devices for language study may result in greater learner engagement with mobile
label: body

text: technology (i.e. mobile devices) and, at the same time, may lead to greater students’
label: body

text: independence in learning the target language.
